text:
[Indication]
Malignant effusion.
[Anesthesia]
Local/None.
[Description]
Talc slurry instilled via existing chest tube. Dwell time and rotation completed. Suction resumed.
[Plan]
Monitor output.

Barbara Perry here for staging ebus. she has a cancer in the right lower lobe. checked the middle nodes station 7 was big. poked it and it is cancer. poked the other ones 4r 4l 10r 11r mostly benign. so she has n2 disease now. needs oncology.

[Indication]
RUL nodule.
[Anesthesia]
GA.
[Description]
Galaxy nav to RB2. Fluoro/rEBUS confirmed. TBNA, Forceps, Brush done.
[Plan]
Discharge.

Mr. Chen was brought to the OR for a rigid bronchoscopy to remove a chicken bone. We inserted the rigid scope and found the bone in the right lower lobe. We grabbed it with forceps and pulled everything out together. The airway looked fine afterwards.

Procedure: Emergent Bronch for Bleed
Patient: Marcus Lee, 62M
Steps:
1. Already intubated.
2. Scope down. Lot of blood.
3. Found bleeder in RUL.
4. Washed with iced saline, gave Epi and TXA.
5. Bleeding stopped.
6. Didn't biopsy anything.
Plan: IR.

Indication: 13mm Lingula nodule.
Technique: Monarch robot. rEBUS concentric. 22G TBNA x5. Brush. No BAL.
ROSE: Atypical/Suspicious.
Comp: None.

Flexible bronchoscopy with BAL and transbronchial biopsies for interstitial lung disease evaluation. Patient is a 53-year-old female with progressive dyspnea and bilateral ground-glass opacities. Moderate sedation with fentanyl and midazolam; native airway. Normal airways to subsegmental level. BAL performed in right middle lobe. Fluoroscopy-guided transbronchial biopsies (6 samples) obtained from right lower lobe lateral basal segment using standard forceps. Mild bleeding controlled with iced saline; no pneumothorax on postprocedure CXR. Discharged home from recovery area.

PT: Davis, K | 64F | #1701625
DT: 10/19/24
MD: R. Johnson
DX: ILD, UIP pattern on imaging, needs tissue dx
PROC: Bronch w/ transbronchial cryobiopsy RLL (CPT 31632)
MEDS: Propofol, fent, roc for intubation
SCOPE FINDINGS:
Airways clear, no endo lesions
TECHNIQUE:

REBUS to RLL lateral basal - no vessels in path
2.4mm cryoprobe advanced to target area
Freeze 6sec x 5 samples total
Arndt blocker inflated 8cc RLL after each, held 3min each time
Samples good size (5-8mm each)
Minimal bleeding, all stopped with blocker

SAMPLES:

5 cryo specimens → histology (ILD protocol)

COMP: None, no PTX on fluoro
DISPO: Extubate, recovery, CXR, d/c if CXR clear
IMP: Successful cryobx. Await path. F/u 1wk.

Billing: 31628 (Transbronchial lung biopsy - Forceps/Cryo distinct from aspiration), 31654 (Radial EBUS guidance).
Note: 31645 (Therapeutic aspiration) is NOT reported as removal of blood/secretions is incidental. 31628 covers the biopsy work. Radial EBUS (31654) documents the search for peripheral lesions/safe sites.

Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for hepatic hydrothorax.
Patient: Samuel Ortiz, 59-year-old male with decompensated cirrhosis and refractory right hepatic hydrothorax.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen ETT.
Indication: Dyspnea and frequent hospitalizations for large right transudative pleural effusion despite sodium restriction and diuretics.
Procedure details: Ultrasound localization identified a large free-flowing right effusion. A 2 cm incision was made in the right 6th intercostal space, midaxillary line. After trocar insertion, 2.1 L of clear, straw-colored fluid was drained. Thoracoscopic inspection showed smooth parietal pleura without nodularity. No suspicious lesions were biopsied. Mechanical abrasion pleurodesis was performed using a thoracoscopic pad; 4 g of sterile talc in 100 mL saline was then distributed evenly. A 24 Fr chest tube was placed posteriorly.
Complications: Transient hypotension corrected with albumin bolus; no bleeding.
Estimated blood loss: 10 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to step-down unit for close monitoring of hemodynamics and chest tube output.
Plan: Albumin replacement for large volume drainage; chest tube to suction initially, then water seal; hepatology consultation regarding TIPS.
